Dear Matthew,

We would appreciate if you could replace the word 'member' to 'participant'.  The UN Global
Compact is not a membership initiative, or rather a network initiative in which companies commit themselves to making progress within their business operation in the areas of the ten
principles.  The Global Compact is entirely about companies that are willing to participate in learning and dialogue, and is not a leadership or membership initiative by which the Global Compact endorses or certifies participating companies as members.  Therefore, it is important that the Global Compact participants identify themselves as 'participating' or 'making commitment' to the initiative.  Thank you for your understanding.
Your request has been approved.

The Sumitomo Corporation Group declared in March 2009 its support for the UN Global Compact's 10 principles. Upon its participation in the Global Compact, the Sumitomo Corporation Group committed itself to make further improvements by constantly assessing enhancements of its business activities in light of the values advocated by the 10 principles.

The Global Compact (GC) was proposed by the former UN Secretary General Kofi Annan at the World Economic Forum (in Davos) in 1999 and officially launched in 2000 at the UN Headquarters in New York. The GC is an initiative aimed at realizing the sustainable growth of the global economy through the voluntary participation of businesses in a worldwide network. The UN invites companies and organizations from around the world to join in the GC and currently has about 6,700 companies and organizations from 129 countries participating. The GC has compiled 10 universal principles recognized by the international community based on international agreements in the areas of human rights, labor, environment and anti-corruption. Participating companies adopt the 10 principles into their business operations and strategies and are expected to assume responsible and creative leadership as a good corporate citizen for the purpose of achieving sustainable growth.

A barrier-free mark (a yellow circle) on the film helps to grasp the direction (up or down) and speed of escalators, so UD Esca contributes to the decrease of accidents where people fall off an escalator or take a wrong one, regardless of their disability, nationality and age.

There are about 70,000 escalators in Japan, and the number is increasing year by year with promotion of the barrier-free facilities. Hi Gerald,

We have reviewed the content of the brochure and would like to request you to make two changes.

1. 2-B item on page 2
We find that the first sentence, starting with ' Your corporation's name...', is not clear and could imply that your sponsors' logos will be presented at the UN Global Compact forums as sponsors, which is incorrect.  Thus, we request you to clarify the language in that respect, or remove the 'UN Global Compact forums' from the item.

2. Third item of More about EVE-olution
We noticed that it is stated that your organization is a member of the UN Global Compact, while this should be a participant. The Global Compact is entirely about companies/organizations that are willing to participate in learning and dialogue, and is not a leadership or membership initiative by which the Global Compact endorses or certifies participating companies/organizations as members. Therefore, we ask you to identify yourself as a 'participant' in the initiative.

Please let us know if these two changes are acceptable.  Thank you.

Thank you for your request. There are only a few issues that need to be addressed in your use of our logos.

1) First, on slide 5, the language describing the Global Compact is somewhat misleading. We would appreciate it if you could use the language found on our website (see: http://www.unglobalcompact.org/AboutTheGC/).

2) Please note that the permission to use the regular GC logo is given only when the Global Compact Office is directly involved in the projected activities.  Therefore, we can only provide you with the endorser (We Support) logo for the purposes of slide 5.

That being said, for the slides directly reciting the Global Compact 10 principles, the regular logo may be used (namely slides 6 through 10), as long as it is made clear on slide 5 that your organization is an endorser of those principles.

Thank you.

Dear Mr. Gooijer. Thank you for uploading your sample. Just a few points: first, the logo that is currently displayed on the page is an old version of the regular GC logo. Please note that the permission to use the regular GC logo is given only when the Global Compact Office is directly involved in the projected activities.  Therefore, we can only provide you with the endorser (We Support) logo. In all materials, the endorser logo must appear in isolation, uncluttered by competing images.

Second, because you have listed the 10 principles in a separate section, the use of the regular logo IS allowed but only in relation to the image of the 10 principles.

Thirdly, we noticed that it is stated that your company is a member of the UN Global Compact, while this should be a participant. The Global Compact is entirely about organizations that are willing to participate in learning and dialogue, and is not a leadership or membership initiative by which the Global Compact endorses or certifies participating entities as members. Therefore, we ask you to identify yourself as 'participating' in the initiative.

For more information on the policy on the use of the UN Global Compact logos, please visit our website at http://www.unglobalcompact.org/AboutTheGC/Global_Compact_Logo/GC_Logo_Policy.html.

Please let me know if these changes would be acceptable.

Thank you.

First, thank you for your support and your training materials are appreciated. However, because the Global Compact was not actually involved in the development of these materials, we cannot grant permission to use our logo as proposed. Before we can grant any logo usage, we would ask that you change the materials in several small but important ways.

First, because the Global Compact was not actually a co-developer of this training material, we would prefer if you did not include our logo on every page of the slides. Rather, placing our logo on the first or last page alone would be preferable.

Second, for these purposes, we can only provide the endorser logo ("We Support"). We cannot grant use of the regular logo with the words "Supported by" as currently used and we ask that you remove that language.

Third, we would prefer if you placed the logos on the front slide, the certificate, and the front page of the manual in a less prominent position, perhaps in the lower corner. This is to make clear that the materials were not in co-authored or otherwise endorsed by the Global Compact. Moreover, it will be clearer that the "We" in "We Support" refers to the JCI.

We hope these changes are acceptable. If you accept these recommendations, we will be able to provide you with higher-quality endorser logos. Please contact us if you have any questions. Thank you.

Dear Christina,

The sample you provided appears to be the main page of your website. If that is the case, we have no problems with granting permission to use the endorser ("We Support") logo. However, you indicated that this was request was for a new section on "memberships and certificates." The Global Compact is entirely about organizations that are willing to participate in learning and dialogue, and is not a leadership or membership initiative by which the Global Compact endorses or certifies participating entities as members. Therefore, we ask you to not use the GC logo in any page/section dealing with memberships or certificates.

For more information on the policy on the use of the UN Global Compact logos, please visit our website at http://www.unglobalcompact.org/AboutTheGC/gc_logo_policy.html.

Please let us know how you wish to proceed. Thank you.

Thank you for your continued support of the Global Compact. In this instance, because the Global Compact did not produce this training material, we can only provide use of our endorser logo ("We Support").
Thank you.

For more information on the policy on the use of the UN Global Compact logos, please visit our website at http://www.unglobalcompact.org/AboutTheGC/gc_logo_policy.html.
